questionText: Which of the following are primary benefits of using Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) for container orchestration?

answers.text: Managed control plane for high availability and upgrades.
Automated scaling of clusters based on resource utilization.
Manual installation and configuration of Kubernetes components on VMs.
Direct access to underlying node operating system for all operations.
Limited integration with other Google Cloud services.
Requirement to manage all node patching and security updates manually.

questionText: When deploying applications on GKE, what are two common deployment strategies for updating your applications with minimal downtime?

answers.text: Rolling update: Gradually replaces old pods with new ones.
Blue/green deployment: Switches traffic from the old version to the new version all at once.
Recreate deployment: Deletes all old pods before creating new ones.
Canary deployment: Releases new versions to a small subset of users first.
A/B testing: Assigns users to different versions based on random selection.
Shadow deployment: Runs new version in parallel with old version and discards its results.

questionText: What are two key components managed by the GKE control plane?

answers.text: Kubernetes API server.
etcd, the distributed key-value store for cluster state.
Worker nodes (Kubelets and container runtimes).
Ingress controllers for external traffic.
Network policies for ingress and egress traffic.
Container Registry for storing images.

questionText: Which two Kubernetes objects are essential for running stateless applications on GKE?

answers.text: Deployment: Manages stateless applications and handles rolling updates.
Service: Provides a stable IP address and DNS name for accessing pods.
StatefulSet: Used for stateful applications requiring stable network identifiers and persistent storage.
DaemonSet: Ensures a copy of a pod runs on all (or some) nodes.
CronJob: Schedules jobs to run at specific times.
ReplicaSet: Manages a stable set of replica Pods (usually managed by Deployments).

questionText: What are two primary methods for exposing applications running on GKE to external traffic?

answers.text: LoadBalancer Service: Provisions an external Google Cloud Load Balancer.
Ingress: Provides HTTP/S load balancing and routing within the cluster.
NodePort Service: Exposes the service on each Node's IP at a static port.
ClusterIP Service: Only exposes the service within the cluster.
ExternalName Service: Maps a Service to a DNS name outside the cluster.
NetworkPolicy: Controls traffic flow between pods and from the internet.

questionText: Which two GKE features enhance security for your containerized workloads?

answers.text: Workload Identity: Provides fine-grained access control to Google Cloud resources from within GKE.
Network Policies: Restrict network traffic between pods.
Public IP address for every pod.
Enabling SSH access to all nodes by default.
Storing secrets in plain text within Pod definitions.
Disabling all authentication for the Kubernetes API.

questionText: What are two key considerations when configuring node pools in GKE?

answers.text: Machine type: Determines the CPU, memory, and GPU resources of the nodes.
Autoscaling settings: Defines the minimum and maximum number of nodes.
Only allowing pods to run on specific node pools regardless of labels.
Forcing all node pools to use the same operating system image.
Disabling automatic node upgrades for all node pools.
Using only ephemeral storage for all node pools.

questionText: Which two Kubernetes concepts are used to manage persistent storage for stateful applications on GKE?

answers.text: PersistentVolume (PV): A piece of storage in the cluster that has been provisioned by an administrator or dynamically.
PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC): A request for storage by a user.
EmptyDir: Provides a temporary directory for pods that exists only for the lifetime of the pod.
ConfigMap: Used to store configuration data, not persistent storage.
Secret: Used to store sensitive information, not persistent storage.
HostPath: Mounts a file or directory on the host node into a pod.

questionText: What are two ways GKE can automatically scale your applications?

answers.text: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA): Scales the number of pod replicas based on CPU or memory utilization.
Cluster Autoscaler: Adjusts the number of nodes in a node pool to meet pod scheduling demands.
Vertical Pod Autoscaler (VPA): Adjusts the resource requests and limits of pods (not scaling the number of pods).
Manual scaling of deployments through kubectl.
Event-driven autoscaling based on custom metrics (requires additional setup).
Auto-provisioning of new clusters based on application load.

questionText: Which two GKE features help improve the reliability and availability of your workloads?

answers.text: Pod Anti-Affinity: Prevents pods from being scheduled on the same node or in the same availability zone.
Pod Disruption Budgets (PDBs): Define the minimum number of pods that must remain running during voluntary disruptions.
Single-zone cluster configuration.
Running all application replicas on a single node.
Manually draining nodes for maintenance without considering application availability.
Disabling health checks for services.

questionText: What are two common use cases for GKE Autopilot?

answers.text: Running stateless web applications and APIs.
Developing and testing new microservices without managing infrastructure.
Hosting high-performance, resource-intensive batch processing jobs requiring fine-grained node control.
Managing large-scale, stateful databases that require specific hardware configurations.
Running specialized machine learning training workloads with custom hardware accelerators.
Deploying custom operating system images with specific kernel modules.

questionText: Which two types of policies can be applied to GKE clusters to manage access and permissions?

answers.text: IAM policies: Control access to Google Cloud resources, including GKE clusters.
Kubernetes Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Controls access to Kubernetes API resources within the cluster.
Network ACLs (Application Level ACLs).
Firewall rules applied directly to pods.
Security Group policies from other cloud providers.
Pod Security Admission policies (though these are enforced by the admission controller, not directly managed as a top-level policy in the same way as IAM/RBAC).

questionText: What are two benefits of using GKE's Managed Node Pools?

answers.text: Automated node image upgrades and patching.
Automatic provisioning and de-provisioning of nodes based on cluster load.
Manual control over every aspect of node OS configuration.
Requirement to manually install Kubernetes components on each node.
No automatic scaling capabilities.
Inability to customize machine types.

questionText: Which two GKE networking features are crucial for managing traffic flow within your cluster and to/from external sources?

answers.text: Services: Abstract pods and provide stable network endpoints.
Ingress: Manages external access to services in a cluster, typically HTTP/S.
NetworkPolicy: Defines how pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints.
ServiceAccount: Manages identity and access for pods within the cluster.
ConfigMap: Stores configuration data, not network traffic management.
PersistentVolumeClaim: Manages storage, not network traffic.

questionText: When deploying applications on GKE, what are two common ways to manage application configuration?

answers.text: ConfigMaps: Store non-sensitive configuration data as key-value pairs.
Secrets: Store sensitive configuration data like passwords and API keys.
Storing configuration directly in container images.
Hardcoding configuration directly into application code.
Using only environment variables for all configuration settings.
Mounting entire host directories into pods for configuration.

questionText: What are two key benefits of using GKE compared to self-managed Kubernetes on Compute Engine?

answers.text: Managed control plane reduces operational overhead.
Automated cluster upgrades and patching.
Full control over Kubernetes master components and their configuration.
No need to worry about networking between nodes.
Complete isolation from Google Cloud services.
Requirement to manually manage all Kubernetes API server certificates.

questionText: Which two GKE features facilitate efficient resource utilization and cost management?

answers.text: Cluster Autoscaler: Adjusts the number of nodes to match workload demands, avoiding over-provisioning.
Resource Requests and Limits in Pod specifications: Ensures pods get the resources they need and prevents runaway resource consumption.
Always over-provisioning nodes to handle peak load.
Disabling autoscaling for node pools.
Running all workloads on the largest available machine types.
Ignoring pod resource requests and limits.

questionText: What are two common scenarios where you would choose GKE Standard over GKE Autopilot?

answers.text: When you need fine-grained control over node OS and configuration.
When deploying workloads with specific networking requirements or custom daemonsets on nodes.
When you want Google to manage all aspects of node infrastructure.
When running simple stateless web applications.
When you want to minimize operational overhead and focus solely on application code.
When you are comfortable with paying for idle node capacity.

questionText: What are two essential components of a GKE cluster that enable communication between pods and services?

answers.text: kube-proxy: Manages network rules on nodes to implement Kubernetes Service concepts.
Container Network Interface (CNI) plugin (e.g., GKE's default network plugin): Provides pod networking.
CoreDNS: Resolves service names to IP addresses within the cluster.
API Server: Manages cluster state and configuration.
etcd: Stores cluster state.
Kubelet: Manages pods on nodes.

questionText: When using GKE, what are two ways to monitor the health and performance of your cluster and applications?

answers.text: Cloud Monitoring (formerly Stackdriver): Provides metrics, dashboards, and alerting for GKE resources.
Cloud Logging (formerly Stackdriver): Collects and analyzes logs from GKE nodes and workloads.
kubectl top commands (limited historical data and alerting capabilities).
Manual SSH access to nodes to check process status.
Disabling all logging and metric collection.
Relying solely on application-level health checks without cluster-level monitoring.

questionText: Which two Kubernetes objects are crucial for managing stateful applications in GKE?

answers.text: StatefulSet: Manages stateful applications, providing stable network identifiers and persistent storage.
PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC): Claims persistent storage for StatefulSet pods.
Deployment: Primarily designed for stateless applications.
Service: Provides network access but doesn't manage state or persistent storage directly.
DaemonSet: Ensures a copy of a pod runs on all (or some) nodes.
ReplicaSet: Manages stateless pods and is typically managed by Deployments.

questionText: What are two methods for securing the images deployed to GKE?

answers.text: Container Analysis: Scans container images for vulnerabilities.
Binary Authorization: Enforces policies on which container images can be deployed.
Using unsigned and unverified container images.
Storing images in public, unencrypted repositories.
Disabling all image scanning and validation.
Allowing deployments from any arbitrary source without verification.

questionText: Which two Kubernetes concepts are used to define the desired state of your applications and their configurations in GKE?

answers.text: YAML manifests: Declarative configuration files that describe Kubernetes resources.
Kubernetes API Objects: The actual representations of resources (like Pods, Deployments, Services) within the cluster.
Imperative commands (e.g., kubectl run without a file).
Directly modifying etcd data.
Shell scripts for managing deployments.
Binary configuration files.

questionText: What are two common considerations when setting up networking for GKE clusters?

answers.text: VPC-native clusters: Use VPC networks for pod IP address management.
Network Policies: Control ingress and egress traffic between pods.
Using public IP addresses for all pods.
Disabling network routing between subnets.
Allowing all inbound traffic to the cluster by default.
Assigning static, non-routable IP addresses to services.

questionText: Which two GKE features help automate the process of managing Kubernetes cluster upgrades?

answers.text: Release channels: Subscribe to different release tracks (Rapid, Regular, Stable) for automatic upgrades.
Manual upgrade commands via `gcloud` or the Cloud Console: Initiate upgrades at a specific time.
Forcing all nodes to be upgraded simultaneously without any phasing.
Disabling automatic upgrades entirely.
Requiring manual patching of every Kubernetes component on every node.
Upgrading only the control plane without considering node upgrades.

questionText: What are two benefits of using GKE's integrated logging and monitoring solutions?

answers.text: Centralized log collection from all cluster components and workloads.
Pre-built dashboards and metrics for Kubernetes and GKE.
Requirement to install and manage separate logging agents on each node.
Limited ability to correlate logs with metrics.
No built-in alerting capabilities.
Data export only to on-premises solutions.
